hints.content:
We can think of $(\blueD{8} \times{\maroonD{3}})\times \greenD{{3}}$ as $(\blueD{8} \times {\maroonD{3}})$ groups of $\greenD{{3}}$. That equals $\purpleC{24}$ groups of $\greenD{3}$.   

![24 groups of 3 dots. The groups are in 8 columns with 3 groups per column](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/81af6ef2bc90530c7e6a35c69fa8530b249741f4)

How can we complete $\blueD{?} \times ({\maroonD{3}}\times {\greenD{3}})$ to get the same total?

$\blueD{?} \times ({\maroonD{3}}\times {\greenD{3}})$ can represent $\blueD{?}$ groups of $\maroonD{3}$ groups of $\greenD{3}$.

![The same dots in 8 groups of 3 groups of 3. ](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/b49567bbaac3be5f0c13ad6e208ff7c7c89552ba)

There are $\blueD{8}$ groups of $\maroonD{3}$ groups of $\greenD{3}$.

We can change the grouping of the factors without changing the total.  

[[☃ explanation 1]]

options.explanation:
As long as we're only multiplying, we can group the factors in any way without changing the total product.

We call that the **associative property of multiplication**.

It does *not* work when we mix multiplication with other operations like addition.

For example:

$\begin{align}
2+(3 \times 4) &\neq (2 + 3) \times 4\\\\
2+12 &\neq 5 \times 4\\\\
14 &\neq 20
\end{align}$
